item.title: Dry conditions fuel spread of wildfires across East Tenn.
item.author: Rachel Wittel
item.description:
Cocke County fire crews teamed up with more than 100 personnel from the U.S. Forest Service and the Tennessee Emergency Management Agency to battle the wildfire blaze ripping across the west side of Stone Mountain.

The wildfire started on Monday afternoon, and has scorched more than 1,000 acres of land as of late Tuesday night.

"Usually at night when the relative humidities come up, the fire will kind of lay low," U.S. Forest Service Information Officer Cheryl Summers said. "But, it burned pretty actively all night last night."  

Summers said the unusually dry weather helped the fire spread faster than expected.

"It's very dry," she said. "We've had an unseasonably dry March, and also, the winds have been so high, so the fires that have started have spread much more than normal."

RELATED: Sevier Co. wildfire evacuation order lifted, arson investigation underway

So far this year, the Tennessee Department of Agriculture's Division of Forestry has recorded 119 wildfires, damaging more than 3,000 acres of land. 

"This is probably the biggest fire season we've seen in several years," Summers said.

Until rain is part of the forecast, she said fire crews will have to keep fighting.

"It will actively burn or keep burning really until we probably get some moisture," she said. "That will hopefully happen tomorrow night."

Although the cause of the Halls Top fire is still under investigation, the U.S. Forest Service says to avoid burning anything at all in these windy and dry conditions.

If you need to burn, call your county's division of forestry for a permit.
